narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The teaching style does not work for me but the content is great
I would recommend this course to anyone.

I appreciate that this class allowed for a lot of flexibility and creativity and that it also was very functional/practical in orientation. I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in policy science. My only suggestion would be to inform students that there would be a lot of reading on the front end of the class and more hands-on project work in the second half. Would help with student planning and preparation. Otherwise excellent course and instruction. Thank you!

The course was very accelerated at the beginning, and I think I missed a lot early on because these concepts are difficult to understand unless you really have time to let them sink in. Susan understands this, however, and doesn't criticize students for not grasping the concepts--she doesn't assume it's because we aren't trying! Knowing that made it a lot easier to keep after the material even when I felt like I was very far behind. I have been continuing to read and re-read the course readings over winter break--a testament to the course, for sure!

The opportunity to attend the COP is amazing, and provides the foundation for the course. In many cases the course was disorganized and unclear - perhaps a result of having a student run course. I suspect the TAs (and thus the class) would have benefited frommore direction from the course Professor. While frustrating during the semester, the lack of organization is more than made up for by the opportunity to attend the COP as a (somewhat) interested party.
This class should be taken by every mem student

This is a very practical course that every environmental manager must take. The concepts of policy science are very useful not only in terms of projects management but also applicable in daily lives. One comment i have is that i would sometimes stuggle to understand what the instructor was saying. It would tough to catch-up with her.
Jenn Hoyle, the TA, did a particularly fabulous job. She worked very hard and made lots of time to talk with us one on one and in small groups about tough issues in the class.
student presentations
The integration of philosophy, psychology and science, and the opportunity to learn from my classmates through presentations.
This class was amazing because I think it has given me a great tool with whcih to strive for a better understanding of policy and how it can be used in striving towards the coomon interest.

Not only did it enhance my way of thinking, but introduced me to thinking about my thinking.Gave me the vocabulary to describe and a method by which to understand a problem.Prof. Clark and Jenn Hoyle were so generous in terms of sharing their time and insightMind maps - great way to capture the complexity of standpoint
Exposure to really useful new way of thinking.
Learning the policy sciences framework.Learning how to apply the frameworkOther people's presentations
the policy framework can be apply to both professional as well as personal realms.
how applicable it is to all problems
Class discussions.

I gained a whole new way of thinking, which I think will be very valuable in my professional career. I already have a renewed excitement for going out into the "real world" and applying these new concepts!
The opportunity to learn more about interdisciplinary approaches to conservation problems.
Attending the COP.
The practical aspect of the policy sciences and its application not only in terms of conservation or projects but also in terms of daily lives.

In my professional work, I have used and worked with some of the functions of the decision process and the five tasks of problem orientation of the policy sciences framework. However, I did not have the tools to analyze, evaluate or reflect on each of these functions and tasks on a theoretical basis. This course provided me with the opportunity to reflect upon the many social and environmental policy issues that I have worked with as a practitioner during the past 15 years. It has helped make the invisible work of thinking and decision making visible.In addition, this course has provided me with new skills and foundations in thinking more effectively and acting more responsibly in complex natural resource policy cases. It has given me tools to integrate, synthesize, and locate the best arenas for interventions that would facilitate problem-resolution. I also feel that I am better equipped with a new set of concepts and terminology of the policy sciences, in particular: awareness knowledge, how-to-knowledge, and principles knowledge.I particularly enjoyed listening and learning about other policy problems and how each student colleague confronted the social and decision process in other to come up with a new problem orientation and problem-solving alternatives and recommendations. This provided all of us an in-depth application of theory to each of our particular cases; a sort of learning by doing.

The pedagogy matched the content--people come first in natural resource management, and people came first in the class. Beginning with a self-orientation and moving on to others, then place, then issues really allows the flow of the ideas to match the structure in which they are presented. It was also neat that this pedagogy was not invisible, but rather quite explicit. That helped build learning and understanding of the content.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: organization and execution of lectures
The professor could better facilitate class discussions by asking more direct, less rhetorical questions.
Some more concrete disection of exmaples would have been useful in this respect.

Balance the reading assignments more. Because there was so much in the first few weeks, I found myself racing through some of the material to keep up. This is not the type of material one can or should race through. Consider assigning some of the ancillary readings (i.e. not from the Policy Process book) for later classes, in order to re-enhance, refresh, and so on understanding certain parts of the policy process.
Fewer students to better facilitate discussion.
It seemed like there were too many presentations. Maybe the class would benefit from being a little smaller so that everyone participates.
devoting less class time to student presentations
The course needs to spend more time addressing practical examples. It also needs to be smaller (no more than 10).

The discussions in the first few weeks of the course could have been more inclusive (they tended to be dominated by a few outspoken students, who Susan continued to call on because they did provide great insights, but it made some of the rest of us feel inferior and made it harder for us to speak up). I also think the readings could have been a stronger focus of the class discussions, which could have hastened our grasp of the material.

1. Putting the policy sciences lingo into words more understandable, useful, and applicable to real-world situations.2. Susan often made it difficult to provide adequate discussion time because students often did not know if her questions were rhetorical or not, the class was too big to have intimate in-depth discussions, students often feel intimidated by Susan, she did not give us enough time to think of responses to her or other's questions, the class table/chair arrangement was inadequate and not conducive to a discussion class, etc.
Organization of course work, expectations, etc. From the first class through to the last class, things felt disorganized.

It was sometimes tough to understand the instructor. We were handed out a lot of handouts which i sometimes struggled to go through. But considering all the four courses i took, i found this one more practical and useful.

1. I recommend that the class conducts an in-depth evaluation of one or two case studies before starting the student presentations (ideally one successful case and one failure of the policy process). We read over the Ecuador case and the different case studies in the handbook, but did not go into much detail about them during our lectures. This will help students visualize the framework in its entirety.2. The Foundations Case Book uses case studies from 1996 and was printed in 2000. It would be interesting to revisit some of these cases and conduct an updated policy analytical framework to see changing trends and conditions and as such, new problem-solving recommendations and alternatives. In addition, I recommend adding new information and cases that can help facilitate the understanding of the policy process and the need for an interdisciplinary focus (as Susan mentioned in our last lecture).3. I believe this class should be a requirement for all FES students. Until we achieve this, I recommend extending a second section of the course (during the spring semester) with more experiential learning skills and methods of the policy process.

While I very much enjoyed presenting and watching some of the other presentations, there's no denying that with this many people in the class a full half semester was devoted to presentations, and that seems too much. Maybe we could present in pairs or small groups instead of individually?Also, while I know that if I had kept my journal faithfully every week it would have been a very useful tool, I was not able to do that and ended up filling in a number of the entries at the end of the semester. I don't know if there's anything to change that, but it would be helpful if Susan or the TA could give a few sample prompts, especially at the beginning and during the student presentations, to help get the juices and motivation flowing.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: great help from TA
The TA was very helpful, especially when preparing for the presentation.
Avilability of Susan and Jennifer throughout the semester was great.
Could not be better - both were unbelievably selfless in offering help. And were effective in helping me understand any uncertainties that I may have had.
Very very available and helpful for both of them.
excellent
excellent from both; they were generous with their time
Instructor and ta were very available for extra help and questions.
Professor Clark and the TA were always available to students and meetings out of class were quite helpful.
They were both extremely available and responsive to student concerns. I'm really appreciative!

1. Jenn was always available and very helpful in helping me understand the policy sciences material.2. Susan was very approachable and willing to talk, but was not always helpful because our meetings would often overlap with other student's meetings with her. She often gave out many articles to read instead of explaining points or concepts herself.
Both the instructor and TA were available one email away.
The availability and quality of help from Susan Clark and Jenn Hoyle was extraordinary. They were always available to assist with course requirements and out-of-class deliberations.
Great. I worked with both on 2-3 occasions, receiving appointments promptly and their full attentions. They were each particularly helpful in their own ways in my preparation for the presentation.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: this class helps people be integrators, which is my career goal
This course is a great foundation to my masters degree. It provides a broad perspective and presents tools for practicing what we learn.
I am interested in the social and decision process of biodiversity conservation. In that regard, this course hit the nail on the head with a sledgehammer.
I am interested in interdisciplinary problem solving and Policy Sciences is a useful tool towards that end.
for someone interested in doing policy analysis and desing it is very useful because it provides a conceptual framework.
I think this course fits very well with all of the programs and everyone should take a course like this before graduating.
This course might even change the emphasis of my overall program. I'm much more interested in policy (and being able to influence it) than I was earlier.

I am in the one-year masters program; so based on the realities and experiences of the "real world", I believe this course is an essential component of the academic foundations needed for future natural resourse practitioners.

It's great, I really appreciate the clarity this course gave me on my overall research topic and it's really hammered home how I need to look at the people first when dealing with a conservation issue.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to understand the policy sciences
The course was highly recommended to me by former students.
Get a solid foundation on natural resource management that I didn't have before.
It was the reason I came to Yale - the policy process, the professor, and the project idea (gaining understanding and perspective on a subject of my own choosing)
I had heard good things about Professor Clark.
I'm interested in policy design and analysis
to become a better problem-solver
It was recommended by other students and I was interested in the topic.
Susan recommended it to me and I heard great things from past students.
I took this course because I thought it would help me understand the roots of environmental problems, and it did just that!
I wanted the opporunity to see how international negotiations work. I wanted to pick a topic, pick an interested stakeholder and get to work.

In my professional work, I have used and worked with some of the functions of the decision process and the five tasks of problem orientation. However, I did not have the tools to analyze, evaluate or reflect on each of these functions and tasks on a theoretical basis. This course provided me with the opportunity to reflect upon the many social and environmental policy issues that I have worked with as a practitioner during the past 15 years. It has helped make the invisible work of thinking and decision making visible.In addition, this course has provided me with new skills and foundations in thinking more effectively and acting more responsibly in complex natural resource policy cases. It has given me tools to integrate, synthesize, and locate the best arenas for interventions that would facilitate problem-resolution. I also feel that I am better equipped with a new set of concepts and terminology of the policy sciences, in particular: awareness knowledge, how-to-knowledge, and principles knowledge
Because I heard during MODs that it was life changing!

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
Yes, and exceeded them.
yes, and even supassed them.
Absolutely.
Yes
yes
for the most part
Mostly outside of learning how to set practical goals across disciplines. This is an essential part needed for problem solving that is lacking in this course.

It exceeded my expectations. During the beginning of the course I wasn't so sure, but after having applied the course concepts to real world situations and re-reading some of the materials, I am really enjoying learning these ideas!

Yes. However, much of the class was devoted to student presentations. While important, it can get very boring and monotonous. I appreciate, however, the opportunity to both give and receive feedback on our presentations.
Yes, except I hoped to be more useful at the COP. The situation with secondary passes and the NGO lockout during the second week made things difficult.
Yes
Yes.
The course lived up to my expectations.
I had very unclear expectations initially, so I guess the course exceeded them.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes, and I am still constantly reflecting on the material I learned.
yes, and more.
Yes. And a bit more.
I didn't know what to expect, but what I got was great.
yes

I have gotten more out of it than expected--I did not think it would give me a whole new way of looking at natural resource problems, and I didn't understand many dimensions of decision-making despite having been involved in it for years. I truly believe I will be a better natural resource decision-maker because of this class.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, more than i expected.

I definately got what I expected.One of the most important aspects I gained from the course was gathering new tools and time to reflect. As it is stated in page 168 of the Foundations class case book:people place a higher value on action the expectation for professionals in conventional settings is to act; not to think or reflect. The single most important element in learning to reflect more effectively and that many professionals lack, is having TIME to reflect.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: great to get student feedback on presentions
N/A
I would not have made it through the class without my POD.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: focus on the readings
Be open minded, esp. to thinking in a very different, and willing to challenge yourself.Don't hesitate to talk with Prof. Clark.
Be open
Be prepared to be self critical.
I think you get what you put into it

This is a great course that has a lot of application. It can polarize people but the key is to continually have an example in your head of how you can apply the information and concepts being taught. If you work through the course in this way, whether you agree or disagree, you will get something out of it in the long run.

Susan suggests that you continue to re-read materials from the previous weeks. Do this! You understand it better each time.If you can, pick a topic for your paper and presentation that you know have been closely involved with--this will help immensely. Also, keep up with your journal entries and know that the end of the semester is going to require a lot of work and long hours.
It is a difficult class because it forces you to approach environmental problems in a very fundamentally different way. Despite the challenges of the material, it is a very worthwhile class.
Try to make contact with a stakeholder as soon as possible. It helps focus your work.
This course is very practical and encourage anyone to take it.
Take it!!! All natural resource practitioners should have awareness and how-to knowledge of the policy sciences framework.
Really put the work into the presentation. It's worth it to give a good one.
